steps.text: Cool the burn under cool running water for at least 20 minutes.
Remove jewellery or tight clothing near the burn, unless stuck to the skin.
Cover the burn with cling film or a clean plastic bag.
If the burn is large, on the face, hands, or genitals — call emergency services below.
Call emergency services below.
Put gloves on if available.
Apply firm pressure directly on the wound with a clean cloth or dressing.
Keep pressure on the wound; add more dressings if soaked - don't remove the first one.
Help the person lie down, keep them warm and still until help arrives.
Sit upright and lean forward slightly (do not tilt head back).
Pinch the soft part of the nose for 10 to 15 minutes.
Breathe through the mouth and remain calm.
If bleeding continues after 20 minutes, call the emergency line.
Keep the injured area still and supported with a splint or soft padding.
Do not try to realign the bone.
Apply an ice pack wrapped in cloth to reduce swelling.
Call emergency medical help immediately.
Rest the injured limb and avoid putting weight on it.
Apply ice for 15 to 20 minutes every hour for the first 24 hours.
Wrap with an elastic bandage to reduce swelling.
Elevate the limb above heart level if possible. Call emergency help if needed.
Ask, 'Are you choking?' and encourage coughing if possible.
If unable to breathe or speak, perform 5 back blows between shoulder blades.
If still choking, perform 5 abdominal thrusts (Heimlich maneuver).
Repeat until the object is expelled or Call emergency help if needed.
Do not induce vomiting unless instructed by a professional.
Call emergency services or poison control immediately.
Provide details about the substance taken and the amount.
Do not give food or drink unless advised.
Move the person to a cool, shaded area.
Cool the body with wet cloths or a fan.
Give small sips of water if the person is conscious.
Call emergency services immediately if confusion or unconsciousness occurs.
Move the person to a warm, dry place.
Remove wet clothing and wrap them in blankets.
Give warm (not hot) drinks if they are conscious.
Call emergency services immediately.
Remove the stinger if visible (scrape it out, do not pinch).
Wash the area with soap and water.
Apply a cold compress to reduce swelling.
Call emergency help if there is an allergic reaction (swelling, difficulty breathing).
Rest the injured limb and avoid putting weight on it.
Apply ice for 15 to 20 minutes every hour for the first 24 hours.
Wrap with an elastic bandage to reduce swelling.
Elevate the limb above heart level if possible. Call emergency help if needed.
Clear the area of sharp or hard objects.
Do not hold the person down or put anything in their mouth.
Place something soft under their head.
After the seizure, turn them on their side and keep them calm.
If more help needed, Call the emergency line.
Do not rub or apply pressure to the eye.
Rinse gently with clean water or saline if a small object is inside.
If a large object is embedded, do not remove it—stabilize and seek medical help immediately.
Cover both eyes to reduce movement then call emergency help.
Lay the person on their back and elevate their legs.
Loosen tight clothing.
If they do not regain consciousness within one minute, call for help.
Check for breathing and pulse.
